trans-unit.source: Provides user interface (UI) elements for logging in to a Web site.
In this topic:
[Introduction](#introduction)
[Style and Templates](#styles_and_templates)
[Validation Groupings](#validation_groupings)
[Accessibility](#accessibility)
[Applying CSS Styles](#applying_styles)
[Declarative Syntax](#declarative_syntax)
Introduction
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control is a composite control that provides all the common UI elements needed to authenticate a user on a Web site.
The following three elements are required for all login scenarios:
A unique user name to identify the user.
A password to verify the identity of the user.
A login button to send the login information to the server.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control also provides the following optional UI elements that support additional functions:
A link for a password reminder.
A Remember Me checkbox for retaining the login information between sessions.
A Help link for users who are having trouble logging in.
A Register New User link that redirects users to a registration page.
Instruction text that appears on the login form.
Custom error text that appears when the user clicks the login button without filling in the user name or password fields.
Custom error text that appears if the login fails.
A custom action that occurs when login succeeds.
A way to hide the login control if the user is already logged in to the site.
For a table showing which controls are required and which are optional, see <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.LayoutTemplate%2A> property.

If you are not familiar with the set of login controls available in ASP.NET, see [ASP.NET Login Controls Overview](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ac032230-6469-4b03-b68d-03ef2643a24d) before continuing.
For a list of other topics related to login controls and membership, see [Managing Users by Using Membership](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/824c3a24-f0af-427c-a652-0d2d1e9397cd).
Accepting user input is a potential security threat.
Malicious users can send data that is intended to expose vulnerabilities or run programs that try generated passwords.
To improve security when working with user input, you should use the validation features of your control and secure any data providers that are configured for your control.

For more information, see [Securing Login Controls](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/d85075bc-9c1a-4453-8a0c-539b10853c9c), [Basic Security Practices for Web Applications](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/3eeeee9e-b09f-4c7f-8ce5-d9ca1f9322ad), and [Securing Membership](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/2dab2012-c278-426a-bb0d-93b260c428a7).
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control uses a membership provider to obtain user credentials.
Unless you specify otherwise, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control uses the default membership provider defined in the Web.config file.
To specify a different provider, set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.MembershipProvider%2A> property to one of the membership provider names defined in your application's Web.config file.
For more information, see [Membership Providers](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/d2c90ff6-aa86-4001-b2c5-e5c99cb7f68f).
If you want to use a custom authentication service, you can use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.OnAuthenticate%2A> method to call the service.
Styles and Templates
The appearance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control is fully customizable through templates and style settings.
All UI text messages are also customizable through properties of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> class.
The default interface text is automatically localized based on the locale setting on the server.

If the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control is customized with templates, then the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebControl.AccessKey%2A> property and the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebControl.TabIndex%2A> property are ignored.

In this case, set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebControl.AccessKey%2A> property and the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebControl.TabIndex%2A> property of each template child control directly.

<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control properties represented by text boxes, such as <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.UserName%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.Password%2A>, are accessible during all phases of the page life cycle.
The control will pick up any changes made by the end user by means of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TextBox.TextChanged> event triggered by the textboxes.

If you embed the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WizardStep> object, explicitly set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Wizard.ActiveStepIndex%2A> property in a `Page_Load` event handler if the user is authenticated.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Wizard> control does not automatically advance to the next <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WizardStep> object in this scenario.
The following table lists the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control style properties and explains which UI element each style property affects.
For a list of which properties each style applies to, see the documentation for the individual style properties.
Style property
UI element affected
The space between the control contents and the control's border.
Remember Me checkbox.
Login failure text.
Instructional text on the page that tells users how to use the control.
Labels for all input fields, such as text boxes.
Text entry input fields.
Title text.
Text displayed to the user when a login attempt is unsuccessful due to validation errors.
Links to other pages.
Login button.
Validation Groupings

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.UserName%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.Password%2A> properties have <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.RequiredFieldValidator> controls associated with them to prevent users from submitting the page without providing required information.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control uses a validation group so that other fields on the same page as the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control can be validated separately.
By default, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.ID%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control is used as the name of the validation group.
For example, a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control with the ID "Login1" will use a validation group name of "Login1".
If you want to set the validation group that the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control is part of, you must template the control and change the validation group name.
Applying CSS Styles
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control lets you specify CSS style rules in markup.
If you use templates to customize the appearance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control, you can specify CSS styles in the markup in the templates.
In that case, no extra outer table is required.
You can prevent the table from being rendered by setting the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.RenderOuterTable%2A> property to `false`.
Accessibility

For information about how to configure this control so that it generates markup that conforms to accessibility standards, see [Accessibility in Visual Studio and ASP.NET](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/7e3ce9c4-6b7d-4fb1-94b5-72cf2a44fe13) and [ASP.NET Controls and Accessibility](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/847a37e3-ce20-41da-b0d3-7dfb0fdae9a0).
Declarative Syntax
Creates a new instance of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login"></xref> control.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> constructor creates a new instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control that can be programmatically inserted into a Web page.
The following table shows the initial property values for a new instance of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login>.
Property
Initial value
"Your login attempt has failed.
Please try again."
"Default"
"Password:"
"Password."
"Remember me next time."
"Login"
"Login"
"User Name:"
"User Name."
Occurs when a user is authenticated.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.Authenticate> event is raised when a user uses the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control to log in to a Web site.
Custom authentication schemes can use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.Authenticate> event to authenticate users.
When a user uses the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control to log in to a Web site, all data in the view state and all post data is lost.
Do not perform actions in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.Authenticate> event that rely on the view state.
For more information about handling events, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
Gets or sets the amount of padding inside the borders of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login"></xref> control.
The value of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.BorderPadding%2A> property is stored in view state.
The amount of space (in pixels) between the contents of a <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login"></xref> control and the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login"></xref> control's border.
The default value is `1`.
The <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.BorderPadding"></xref> property is set to a value less than -1.
Gets a reference to a <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Style"></xref> object that defines the settings for the Remember Me check box.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.CheckBoxStyle%2A> property gets a reference to a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Style> object that you use to change the appearance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control's Remember Me check box.
This property is read-only; however, you can set the properties of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Style> object it returns.

You can set these properties declaratively in the form `Property-Subproperty`, where `Subproperty` represents a property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Style> class (for example, `CheckBoxStyle-ForeColor`).
You can set the property programmatically in the form `Property.Subproperty` (for example, `CheckBoxStyle.ForeColor`).
Common settings include custom background color, text color, and font properties.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.CheckBoxStyle%2A> property defines the appearance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.RememberMeText%2A> property.
The style settings for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.CheckBoxStyle%2A> property are merged with the style settings for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.
Any settings made in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.CheckBoxStyle%2A> property override the corresponding settings in properties of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.
The following <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control style properties are overridden by <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.CheckBoxStyle%2A> settings:
When you use templates to define the appearance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.CheckBoxStyle%2A> property has no effect.
A reference to the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Style"></xref> that defines the style settings for the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login"></xref> control's Remember Me check box.
Creates the individual controls that make up the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login"></xref> control and associates event handlers with their events.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.CreateChildControls%2A> method creates instances of the controls that compose the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.
Gets the location of an image to display next to the link to a registration page for new users.
The URL of the image to display.
The default is <xref href="System.String.Empty"></xref>.
Gets or sets the text of a link to a registration page for new users.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.CreateUserText%2A> property contains the text of a link to the registration page for the site.
The URL of the registration page is specified in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.CreateUserUrl%2A> property.

If <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.CreateUserUrl%2A> is empty, the text in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.CreateUserText%2A> property is displayed to the user, but is not formatted as a link.
If the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.CreateUserText%2A> property is empty, a link to the registration page is not available to the user.
The value of this property, when set, can be saved automatically to a resource file by using a designer tool.
For more information, see <xref:System.ComponentModel.LocalizableAttribute> and [Globalization and Localization](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/8ef3838e-9d05-4236-9dd0-ceecff9df80d).
The text of the link to the new-user registration page.
The default is <xref href="System.String.Empty"></xref>.
Gets or sets the URL of the new-user registration page.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.CreateUserUrl%2A> property contains the URL of the new-user registration page for the Web site.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.CreateUserText%2A> property contains the text used for the link.
If the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.CreateUserText%2A> property is empty, the link to the registration page is unavailable to the user.
The URL of the new-user registration page.
The default is <xref href="System.String.Empty"></xref>.
Gets or sets the URL of the page displayed to the user when a login attempt is successful.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.DestinationPageUrl%2A> property specifies the page that is displayed when a login attempt is successful.

The default behavior of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control is to return the user to the referring page, or to the page defined in the `defaultUrl` attribute of the element in the Web.config file.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.DestinationPageUrl%2A> property overrides the default behavior of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control, as well as the `defaultUrl` setting made in the configuration file.
This property cannot be set by themes or style sheet themes.
For more information, see <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> and [ASP.NET Themes and Skins](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/5df3ebbd-d46c-4502-9406-02f9df4ef2c3).
The URL of the page the user is redirected to when a login attempt is successful.
The default is <xref href="System.String.Empty"></xref>.
Gets or sets a value indicating whether to display a check box to enable the user to control whether a persistent cookie is sent to their browser.

When the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.DisplayRememberMe%2A> property is set to `true`, the text contained in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.RememberMeText%2A> property is displayed on the page, along with a Remember Me check box.
When the user selects the Remember Me check box, the authentication cookie sent to his or her computer persists so that the user is automatically authenticated on future visits to the site.
The value of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.RememberMeSet%2A> property is set by the selection in the Remember Me check box.

If <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.DisplayRememberMe%2A> is `false`, a Remember Me check box is not displayed on the page and the user has no way to control whether the authentication cookie persists or not.
You can still set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.RememberMeSet%2A> property to `true` to send a persistent authentication cookie to the user's browser without displaying the check box.
There are inherent security risks with setting a persistent authentication cookie on a user's browser.
You should determine whether these security risks are acceptable to your site.

If you set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.RememberMeSet%2A> property to `true` and the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.DisplayRememberMe%2A> property to `false`, users visiting your Web site from public browsers, as in Internet cafes for example, can accidentally leave persistent authentication cookies behind and the next user of the browser will be able to access your Web site using the previous user's credentials.
This property cannot be set by themes or style sheet themes.
For more information, see <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> and [ASP.NET Themes and Skins](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/5df3ebbd-d46c-4502-9406-02f9df4ef2c3).
`true` to display the check box; otherwise, `false`.
The default is `true`.
Gets or sets the action that occurs when a login attempt fails.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.FailureAction%2A> property defines the behavior of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control when the user does not successfully log in to the Web site.
The default behavior reloads the page and displays the contents of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.FailureText%2A> property to alert the user that the login attempt failed.

When <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.FailureAction%2A> is set to <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginFailureAction.RedirectToLoginPage>, the user is redirected to the login page defined in the Web.config file.
This property cannot be set by themes or style sheet themes.
For more information, see <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> and [ASP.NET Themes and Skins](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/5df3ebbd-d46c-4502-9406-02f9df4ef2c3).
One of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginFailureAction"></xref> enumeration values.
The default is <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginFailureAction.Refresh"></xref>.
The selected value is not one of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginFailureAction"></xref> enumeration values.
Gets or sets the text displayed when a login attempt fails.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.FailureText%2A> property specifies the string that is displayed when a login attempt fails.

If you define a template for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control, you can indicate where on the template to display the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.FailureText%2A> property by using a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Literal> control and giving that control the ID "FailureText".

When you use a template, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.FailureTextStyle%2A> property is not applied to the text specified in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.FailureText%2A> property.
The default text for the property is localized based on the server's current locale.
For security reasons, the login failure text should not include a specific reason for the failure.
For example, an error message such as "Password not valid for user \<username>" reveals to a potential attacker that \<username> is a user on the system.
For more information, see [How to: Display Safe Error Messages](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/6f70ac33-6e11-4e98-ab7d-bae9c0e7eefa).
The value of this property, when set, can be saved automatically to a resource file by using a designer tool.
For more information, see <xref:System.ComponentModel.LocalizableAttribute> and [Globalization and Localization](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/8ef3838e-9d05-4236-9dd0-ceecff9df80d).
The text to display to the user when a login attempt fails.
The default is "Your login attempt has failed.
Please try again."
Gets a reference to a collection of properties that define the appearance of error text in the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login"></xref> control.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.FailureTextStyle%2A> property gets a reference to a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TableItemStyle> object that you use to change the appearance of login failure text.
The default is to display the text in red.
This property is read-only; however, you can set the properties of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TableItemStyle> object it returns.

You can set these properties declaratively in the form `Property-Subproperty`, where `Subproperty` represents a property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TableItemStyle> class (for example, `FailureTextStyle-ForeColor`).
You can set the property programmatically in the form `Property.Subproperty` (for example, `FailureTextStyle.ForeColor`).
Common settings include custom background color, text color, and font properties.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.FailureTextStyle%2A> property defines the appearance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.FailureText%2A> property.
The style settings for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.FailureTextStyle%2A> property are merged with the style settings for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.
Any settings made in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.FailureTextStyle%2A> property override the corresponding settings in properties of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.
The following <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control style properties are overridden by <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.FailureTextStyle%2A> settings:
When you use templates to define the appearance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.FailureTextStyle%2A> property has no effect.
A reference to the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.TableItemStyle"></xref> that contains properties that define the appearance of error text.
Gets the location of an image to display next to the link to the login Help page.
The URL of the image to display.
The default is <xref href="System.String.Empty"></xref>.
Gets or sets the text of a link to the login Help page.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.HelpPageText%2A> property contains the link text to the login Help page for the site.
The URL of the login Help page is specified in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.HelpPageUrl%2A> property.

If <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.HelpPageUrl%2A> is empty, the text in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.HelpPageText%2A> property is displayed to the user on the page, but is not formatted as a link.
If the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.HelpPageText%2A> property is empty, the link to the login Help page is not available to the user.
The value of this property, when set, can be saved automatically to a resource file by using a designer tool.
For more information, see <xref:System.ComponentModel.LocalizableAttribute> and [Globalization and Localization](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/8ef3838e-9d05-4236-9dd0-ceecff9df80d).
The text of the link to the login Help page.
The default is <xref href="System.String.Empty"></xref>.
Gets or sets the URL of the login Help page.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.HelpPageUrl%2A> property contains the URL of the login Help page for the Web site.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.HelpPageText%2A> property contains the text used for the link.

If <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.HelpPageUrl%2A> is empty, text in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.HelpPageText%2A> property is displayed to the user, but is not formatted as a link.
If the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.HelpPageText%2A> property is empty, the link to the login Help page is not available to the user.
The URL of the login Help page.
The default is <xref href="System.String.Empty"></xref>.
Gets a reference to a collection of properties that define the appearance of hyperlinks in the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login"></xref> control.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.HyperLinkStyle%2A> property defines the appearance of hyperlinks in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.
This property is read-only; however, you can set the properties of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TableItemStyle> object it returns.

You can set these properties declaratively in the form `Property-Subproperty`, where `Subproperty` represents a property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TableItemStyle> class (for example, `HyperLinkStyle-ForeColor`).
You can set the property programmatically in the form `Property.Subproperty` (for example, `HyperLinkStyle.ForeColor`).
Common settings include custom background color, text color, and font properties.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.HyperLinkStyle%2A> property defines the appearance of the following properties:
The style settings for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.HyperLinkStyle%2A> property are merged with the style settings for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.
Any settings made in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.HyperLinkStyle%2A> property override the corresponding settings in properties of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.
The following <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> style properties are overridden by <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.HyperLinkStyle%2A> settings:
When you use templates to define the appearance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.HyperLinkStyle%2A> property has no effect.
A reference to the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.TableItemStyle"></xref> that contains properties that define the appearance of hyperlinks.
Gets or sets login instruction text for the user.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.InstructionText%2A> property contains instructions for users logging in to the Web site.
This text is displayed in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control, following the title.
If the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.InstructionText%2A> property is set to <xref:System.String.Empty>, no instruction text is available to the user.
The value of this property, when set, can be saved automatically to a resource file by using a designer tool.
For more information, see <xref:System.ComponentModel.LocalizableAttribute> and [Globalization and Localization](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/8ef3838e-9d05-4236-9dd0-ceecff9df80d).
The login instruction text to display to the user.
The default is <xref href="System.String.Empty"></xref>.

Gets a reference to a <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.TableItemStyle"></xref> object that defines the settings for instruction text in the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login"></xref> control.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.InstructionTextStyle%2A> property defines the appearance of instruction text in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.
This property is read-only; however, you can set the properties of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TableItemStyle> object it returns.

You can set these properties declaratively in the form `Property-Subproperty`, where `Subproperty` represents a property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TableItemStyle> class (for example, `InstructionTextStyle-ForeColor`).
You can set the property programmatically in the form `Property.Subproperty` (for example, `InstructionTextStyle.ForeColor`).
Common settings include custom background color, text color, and font properties.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.InstructionTextStyle%2A> property defines the appearance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.InstructionText%2A> property.
The style settings for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.InstructionTextStyle%2A> property are merged with the style settings for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.

Any settings made in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.InstructionTextStyle%2A> property override the corresponding settings in properties of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.
The following <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> style properties are overridden by <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.InstructionTextStyle%2A> settings:
When you use templates to define the appearance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.InstructionTextStyle%2A> property has no effect.
A reference to the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.TableItemStyle"></xref> that contains the style settings of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login"></xref> control instruction text.
Gets a reference to a <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.TableItemStyle"></xref> object that defines the settings for <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login"></xref> control labels.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.LabelStyle%2A> property defines the appearance of text box labels in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.
This property is read-only; however, you can set the properties of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TableItemStyle> object it returns.

You can set these properties declaratively in the form `Property-Subproperty`, where `Subproperty` represents a property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TableItemStyle> class (for example, `LabelStyle-ForeColor`).
You can set the property programmatically in the form `Property.Subproperty` (for example, `LableStyle.ForeColor`).
Common settings include custom background color, text color, and font properties.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.LabelStyle%2A> property defines the appearance of the following properties:
The style settings for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.LabelStyle%2A> property are merged with the style settings for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.
Any settings made in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.LabelStyle%2A> property override the corresponding settings in properties of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.
The following <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> style properties are overridden by <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.LabelStyle%2A> settings:
When you use templates to define the appearance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.LabelStyle%2A> property has no effect.
A reference to the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.TableItemStyle"></xref> that defines the style settings of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login"></xref> control labels.
Gets or sets the template used to display the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login"></xref> control.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.LayoutTemplate%2A> property contains the template that defines how the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control is displayed to the user.
The following table lists the required and optional controls used in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control template.
ID or command name
Control type
Required/optional
Any control that implements <xref:System.Web.UI.IEditableTextControl>, including <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TextBox>, or a custom or third-party control.
Required
Any control that implements <xref:System.Web.UI.IEditableTextControl>, including <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TextBox>, or a custom or third-party control.
Required
Optional
Any control that implements <xref:System.Web.UI.ITextControl>.
Optional
Any control that causes event bubbling.
Optional
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control throws an <xref:System.Web.HttpException> exception if the layout template does not contain the required controls.
No exception is thrown if you give an optional control ID to a control of the wrong type; however, the control is subsequently ignored by the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.

The login control can be any control that causes event bubbling, such as <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Button>, <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton>, or <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ImageButton>.
The control's command name property must be set to "Login".

Occurs when the user logs in to the Web site and has been authenticated.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.LoggedIn> event is raised after the authentication provider checks the user's credentials and the authentication cookie is queued to send to the browser in the next response.
Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.LoggedIn> event to provide additional processing, such as accessing per-user data, after the user is authenticated.

When a user submits his or her login information, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control first raises the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.LoggingIn> event, then the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.Authenticate> event, and finally the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.LoggedIn> event.
When a user uses the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control to log in to a Web site, all data in the view state and all post data is lost.
Do not perform actions in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.LoggedIn> event that rely on the view state.
For more information about handling events, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
Occurs when a user submits login information, before authentication takes place.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.LoggingIn> event is raised when a user submits login information but before the user is authenticated on the Web site.
Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.LoggingIn> event to set up any information that you need before authenticating a user.

You can cancel a login attempt during the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.LoggingIn> event by setting the <xref:System.ComponentModel.CancelEventArgs.Cancel%2A> property of the <xref:System.ComponentModel.CancelEventArgs> object to `true`.

After the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.LoggingIn> event is raised, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control raises the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.Authenticate> event and then the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.LoggedIn> event.
For more information about handling events, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
Represents the command name associated with the login button.
<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.LoginButtonCommandName> is a read-only field and the default value is "Login".
This value is passed to the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.OnBubbleEvent%2A>, and if the value is "Login", the control attempts to log in the current user.
Gets or sets the URL of an image to use for the login button.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.LoginButtonImageUrl%2A> property contains the URL of the image rendered as the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control login button when the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.LoginButtonType%2A> property is set to <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ButtonType.Image>.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.LoginButtonText%2A> property is used as the alternative text for the image in browsers that do not display images.
The URL of the image used for the login button.
The default is <xref href="System.String.Empty"></xref>.

Occurs when a login error is detected.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.LoginError> event is raised when the credentials entered by the user are invalid.
You can use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.LoginError> event to redirect the user to a custom error page, to offer additional help, or to log failed login attempts.

Gets or sets the name of the membership data provider used by the control.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.MembershipProvider%2A> property contains the name of the data provider that provides the authentication information for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.
Valid membership provider names are defined in the `<membership>` element in your application's Machine.config or Web.config file.
If you do not set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.MembershipProvider%2A> property, it will always return <xref:System.String.Empty>.
For more information, see the <xref:System.Web.Security.Membership> class.

The values of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.UserName%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.Password%2A> are not available during the `Page_Load` phase, but are during the `Pre_Render` phase.

If <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.PasswordRecoveryUrl%2A> is empty, the text in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.PasswordRecoveryText%2A> property is displayed to the user, but is not formatted as a link.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.PasswordRecoveryText%2A> property contains the text used for the link.
If the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.PasswordRecoveryText%2A> property is empty, the link to the password recovery page is not available to the user.
The URL of the password recovery page.
The default is <xref href="System.String.Empty"></xref>.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.PasswordRequiredErrorMessage%2A> property contains the error message displayed in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ValidationSummary> control on the login page.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.PasswordRequiredErrorMessage%2A> property value is displayed only when both the following conditions are true:
A <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ValidationSummary> control is present on the page.
The Password text box is left blank by the user.

Both the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.PasswordRequiredErrorMessage%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.UserNameRequiredErrorMessage%2A> values are wrapped in a validation group within the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.

For these values to display, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ValidationSummary.ValidationGroup%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ValidationSummary> control must be set to the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.ID%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.
The error message to display in a <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.ValidationSummary"></xref> control when the password field is left blank.
The default is "Password."
Gets or sets a value indicating whether to send a persistent authentication cookie to the user's browser.

When the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.RememberMeSet%2A> property is `true`, the authentication cookie sent to the user's computer is set to expire in 50 years, making it a persistent cookie that will be used when the user next visits the Web site.
Because the authentication cookie will be present on the user's computer, the user will be considered already authenticated and will not have to log in to the Web site again.

When the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.DisplayRememberMe%2A> property is `true`, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.RememberMeSet%2A> property is set to the value of the check box displayed to the user.

If the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.DisplayRememberMe%2A> property is `false`, a Remember Me check box is not displayed on the page and the user has no way to control whether the authentication cookie is persistent.
If the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.RememberMeSet%2A> property is `true`, the authentication cookie sent to the user's browser will be a persistent cookie.

If the user logs out of the Web site using the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus> control, the persistent cookie is cleared from the user's computer and the user will have to log in to the site on the next visit.
There are inherent security risks with setting a persistent authentication cookie on a user's browser.
You should determine whether these security risks are acceptable to your site.

If you set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.RememberMeSet%2A> property to `true` and the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.DisplayRememberMe%2A> property to `false`, users visiting your Web site from public browsers, as in Internet cafes for example, can accidentally leave persistent authentication cookies behind and the next user of the browser will be able to access your Web site using the previous user's credentials.
This property cannot be set by themes or style sheet themes.
For more information, see <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> and [ASP.NET Themes and Skins](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/5df3ebbd-d46c-4502-9406-02f9df4ef2c3).
`true` to send a persistent authentication cookie; otherwise, `false`.
The default value is `false`.
Gets or sets the text of the label for the Remember Me check box.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.RememberMeText%2A> property contains the text of the label for the Remember Me <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.CheckBox> control.
The default text for the property is localized based on the server's current locale.
The value of this property, when set, can be saved automatically to a resource file by using a designer tool.
For more information, see <xref:System.ComponentModel.LocalizableAttribute> and [Globalization and Localization](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/8ef3838e-9d05-4236-9dd0-ceecff9df80d).
The text of the label for the Remember Me check box.
The default is "Remember me next time."
Renders the login form using the specified HTML writer.
The HMTL writer.
Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the control encloses rendered HTML in a `table` element in order to apply inline styles.

In order to make inline style properties such as <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebControl.ForeColor%2A> apply to all the HTML that is rendered for the control, ASP.NET encloses the rendered HTML in a `table` element.
If you do not want the outer `table` element to be rendered, set this property to `false`.
In that case, if you try to set inline style properties that apply to the whole control, an exception is thrown.
`true` if the control encloses rendered HTML in a `table` element; otherwise, `false`.
The default is `true`.
Saves any state that was modified after the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Style.TrackViewState"></xref> method was invoked.
An object that contains the current view state of the control; otherwise, if there is no view state associated with the control, `null`.
Sets design-time data for a control.
An <xref href="System.Collections.IDictionary"></xref> containing the design-time data for the control.
Gets the <xref href="System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriterTag"></xref> value that corresponds to a <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login"></xref> control.
This property is used primarily by control developers.

Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.TagKey%2A> property to determine the <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriterTag> value that is associated with a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.
This property is used primarily by control developers.
Always returns <xref href="System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriterTag.Table"></xref>.
Gets a reference to a collection of properties that define the appearance of text boxes in the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login"></xref> control.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.TextBoxStyle%2A> property defines the appearance of the User name and Password <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TextBox> controls in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.
This property is read-only; however, you can set the properties of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Style> object it returns.

You can set these properties declaratively in the form `Property-Subproperty`, where `Subproperty` represents a property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Style> class (for example, `TextBoxStyle-ForeColor`).
You can set the property programmatically in the form `Property.Subproperty` (for example, `TextBoxStyle.ForeColor`).
Common settings include custom background color, text color, and font properties.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.TextBoxStyle%2A> property defines the appearance of the user name and password text boxes.
The style settings for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.TextBoxStyle%2A> property are merged with the style settings for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.
Any settings made in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.TextBoxStyle%2A> property override the corresponding settings in properties of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.
The following <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> style properties are overridden by <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.TextBoxStyle%2A> settings:
When you use templates to define the appearance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.TextBoxStyle%2A> property has no effect.
A reference to the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Style"></xref> that contains properties that define the appearance of text boxes.
Specifies the position of each label relative to its associated text box for the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login"></xref> control.

You can use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.TextLayout%2A> property to specify the position of labels relative to their associated text boxes for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.
This property is set using one of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginTextLayout> enumeration values.
The following table lists the possible values.
LoginTextLayout value
Description
Places labels to the left of the associated text entry fields.
Places labels above the associated text entry fields.
One of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginTextLayout"></xref> enumeration values.
The default is <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginTextLayout.TextOnLeft"></xref>.
The selected value is not one of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginTextLayout"></xref> enumeration values.
Gets or sets the title of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login"></xref> control.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.TitleText%2A> property specifies the title displayed at the top of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.
The default text for the control is localized based on the server's current locale.
The value of this property, when set, can be saved automatically to a resource file by using a designer tool.
For more information, see <xref:System.ComponentModel.LocalizableAttribute> and [Globalization and Localization](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/8ef3838e-9d05-4236-9dd0-ceecff9df80d).
The title of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login"></xref> control.
The default is "Login".
Gets a reference to a collection of properties that define the appearance of the title text in the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login"></xref> control.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.TitleTextStyle%2A> property gets a reference to a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TableItemStyle> object that you use to change the appearance of the title contained in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.TitleText%2A> property.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.TitleTextStyle%2A> property defines the appearance of the title in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.
This property is read-only; however, you can set the properties of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TableItemStyle> object it returns.

You can set these properties declaratively in the form `Property-Subproperty`, where `Subproperty` represents a property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TableItemStyle> class (for example, `TitleStyle-ForeColor`).
You can set the property programmatically in the form `Property.Subproperty` (for example, `TitleStyle.ForeColor`).
Common settings include custom background color, text color, and font properties.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.TitleTextStyle%2A> property defines the appearance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.TitleText%2A> property.
The style settings for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.TitleTextStyle%2A> property are merged with the style settings for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.
Any settings made in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.TitleTextStyle%2A> property override the corresponding settings in properties of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.
The following <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> style properties are overridden by <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.TitleTextStyle%2A> settings:
When you use templates to define the appearance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.TitleTextStyle%2A> property has no effect.
A reference to the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.TableItemStyle"></xref> that contains properties that define the appearance of title text.
Overrides the base <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control.TrackViewState"></xref> method.
Gets the user name entered by the user.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.UserName%2A> property contains the user name entered by the user.

<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control properties represented by text boxes, such as <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.UserName%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.Password%2A>, are accessible during all phases of the page life cycle.
The control will pick up any changes made by the end user by means of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TextBox.TextChanged> event triggered by the textboxes.
The user name entered by the user.
The default is <xref href="System.String.Empty"></xref>.
Gets or sets the text of the label for the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.UserName"></xref> text box.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.UserNameLabelText%2A> property contains the label text for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.UserName%2A> text box.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.TextLayout%2A> property defines where the field label is positioned.
The default text for the control is localized based on the server's current locale.
The value of this property, when set, can be saved automatically to a resource file by using a designer tool.
For more information, see <xref:System.ComponentModel.LocalizableAttribute> and [Globalization and Localization](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/8ef3838e-9d05-4236-9dd0-ceecff9df80d).
The text of the label for the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.UserName"></xref> text box.
The default is "User Name:".
Gets or sets the error message to display in a <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.ValidationSummary"></xref> control when the user name field is left blank.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.UserNameRequiredErrorMessage%2A> property contains the error message displayed in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ValidationSummary> control on the login page.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.UserNameRequiredErrorMessage%2A> property value is displayed only when both the following conditions are true:
A <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ValidationSummary> control is present on the page.
The User name text box is left blank by the user.
The default text for the control is localized based on the server's current locale.
The value of this property, when set, can be saved automatically to a resource file by using a designer tool.
For more information, see <xref:System.ComponentModel.LocalizableAttribute> and [Globalization and Localization](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/8ef3838e-9d05-4236-9dd0-ceecff9df80d).

Both the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.PasswordRequiredErrorMessage%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.UserNameRequiredErrorMessage%2A> values are wrapped in a validation group within the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.

For these values to display, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ValidationSummary.ValidationGroup%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ValidationSummary> control must be set to the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.ID%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control.
The error message to display in a <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.ValidationSummary"></xref> control when the user name field is left blank.
The default is "User Name."

Gets or sets a value indicating whether to show the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login"></xref> control after the user is authenticated.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.VisibleWhenLoggedIn%2A> property specifies whether the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control is displayed to authenticated users.
When the property is `false`, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control does not appear on the page when an authenticated user accesses the site.
This is used on Web pages that are used both as login pages and as information pages to hide the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control after the user has been authenticated.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login.VisibleWhenLoggedIn%2A> property has no effect on a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login> control that appears on the default login page defined in Web.config or in the application's configuration file.
This property cannot be set by themes or style sheet themes.
For more information, see <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> and [ASP.NET Themes and Skins](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/5df3ebbd-d46c-4502-9406-02f9df4ef2c3).
`false` if the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Login"></xref> control should be hidden when the user is authenticated; otherwise, `true`.
The default is `true`.
